subject: Re: [junit] JUnit 4.0 release candidate 2 Test.None
msgSnippet: ... Why should it be non-public? Although it is the default, I could imagine a situation where you would want to note explicitly that no exception is expected
messageBody:
On 20/01/06, Elliotte Harold <elharo@...> wrote:
> David Saff wrote:
>
> > None is the default value of the expected attribute on the Test
> > annotation. It is not intended for outside use. Thanks,
>
> Can this be made non-public then?

Why should it be non-public?

Although it is the default, I could imagine a situation where you
would want to note explicitly that no exception is expected from a
test. If the None value was non-public, this would not be possible.

(Most likely situation: several test cases that do expect exceptions,
with one that doesn't - the use of None would document very clearly
that the exception is not expected)

--
"Software is too expensive to build cheaply"
Robert Watkins http://twasink.net/ robertdw@...
